descript.abstract: Each image in a TerraLook collection is rendered in simulated natural color and distributed in JPEG format. The JPEG file format and simulated natural color scheme were selected to make TerraLook images accessible to a wide audience. TerraLook JPEG files are small in size, which makes them quick to download and display using Web browsers and other commonly available software packages. Simulated natural colors are generally easy to interpret and understand. The simulated natural colors in TerraLook images are consistently processed so that images from four time periods -- circa 1975, 1990, 2000, and the present -- can be compared through time. The simulated natural color images use the green, red and NIR source image bands as follows: Red = R; Green = 2/3 * G + 1/3 * NIR; Blue = 2/3 * G - 1/3 * NIR.
descript.purpose: Landsat and other satellite sensors have been collecting images of the Earth from space for more than 30 years. For the most part, the use of satellite images has been limited to the scientific and land management communities. TerraLook is intended to broaden the satellite data user community by providing both ASTER and the Tri-Decadal Global Landsat Orthorectified data (from three different epochs) as simulated natural color JPEG images. TerraLook aims to serve the education and natural resource management communities by meeting the need for easily accessible GIS-ready remotely-sensed data. TerraLook collections will be of value to anyone who wants to see the changes to the Earth's surface over the last 30 years. TerraLook images are designed for visual interpretation and display.
descript.supplinf:
The image is stored in the TerraLook Collection "images" directory.
This TerraLook image is derived from an ASTER image (http://eros.usgs.gov/products/satellite/aster.html) from the Land Processes Distribued Active Archive Center at USGS EROS. The Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer (ASTER) is one of a number of instruments on board the Terra platform, which was launched in December 1999. ASTER provides fourteen spectral bands with 15- to 90-meter resolution depending on bands. ASTER does not acquire data continuously, and its sensors are activated only to collect specific scenes upon request. The instrument consists of three separate telescopes, each of which provides different spectral range and resolution. The VNIR (visible and near-infrared) sensor provides 4 bands at 15-meter resolution. The SWIR (short-wave infrared) sensor provides 6 bands at 30-meter resolution. The TIR (thermal infrared) sensor provides 5 bands at 90-meter resolution. The swath width for all sensors is 60 kilometers. TerraLook images use the green, red and NIR bands from the VNIR sensor.

idinfo.datacred: TerraLook builds on the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory's Protected Area Archive project (http://asterweb.jpl.nasa.gov/TerraLook.asp).
idinfo.useconst: None. Acknowledgement of the USGS EROS and NASA JPL would be appreciated in products derived from this data.

enttyp.enttypd: The band label is its color in rgb space

attr.attrdef: 2/3 green band +1/3 NIR band from source image
2/3 green band - 1/3 NIR band from source image

overview.eaover: The three bands form an RGB simulated-natural color image

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata
metainfo.metus: None. Acknowledgement of the USGS EROS and NASA JPL would be appreciated in products derived from this data.

cntorgp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey Earth Resources Observation & Science (EROS)

procstep.procdesc: Generate TerraLook simulated natural color product from ASTER image

horizpa.horizpar: The ASTER User's Guide (2003) at http://www.science.aster.ersdac.or.jp/en/documnts/users_guide/ documents of the accuracy of the Level 1 products at better than 50 meters at nadir. JPEG compressed with quality of .80 will yield a rule-of-thumb horizontal degradation of 2, which will be highly variable depending on local image texture.
